instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message: So I am working on a MBA with an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is steady at 3.42v, but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.18v. I checked the resistance of pins 27 & 28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and get 20.2 Ohms and 3.3 Ohms on pins 17 & 18. I checked in diode mode on L7520 and it comes up as .01v drop on both sides. Not sure where to go from there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message:
Start checking <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, if no Magsafe light present.
Next, diode mode to ground on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus; also check the voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51736"]Start checking <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, if no Magsafe light present.
Next, diode mode to ground on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus; also check the voltage.[/QUOTE]


No Magsafe light is present.

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.37v

SCL:
Diode mode is .540v
V= 2.72v

SDA:
Diode mode is .537v
V=3.42v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message:
"V= 2.72v"
Are you sure about this?

Change <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> first.
If still the same, change SMC.
You can try to reflow/reball SMC before replace it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 51746"]"V= 2.72v"
Are you sure about this?

Change <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> first.
If still the same, change SMC.
You can try to reflow/reball SMC before replace it.[/QUOTE]

Double checked SCL and it is 2.72v. I will replace the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>. If that doesn't work I will first reflow then replace SMC & report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message: Changed <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and still the same. I tried to reflow SMC but it came off board... Looked like some pads on the bottom of the chip were gone. So I will replace it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message:
Please do NOT quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Try to maintain forum aesthetics...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message: Got it. One question: Before replacing the SMC I found <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is shorted. I tested via L7520. Even with the SMC removed. Is this a separate issue? Can I remove L7520 and inject voltage here to find a short? I checked this vs 5 other working machines and found that the short I am getting is an abnormal condition. This is not a customer machine BTW, just an experimental project of mine. This is by far the most interesting issue I have ran into so I am pursuing it for the understanding and education.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message:
Why did you remove SMC?
It is not connected to any 5V rail.

You can try injecting voltage; if is really short, or very low value to ground.
Start with 1V and go up...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.18v
threads.message: I removed the SMC by accident... I had the air up on my hot air station up too high and not enough flux. Doesn't help that I am now using a bent nozzle when I am used to straight ones. Before I took it off I noticed the that the goo on the corners of the SMC was brown like someone burned it. I'll try injecting voltage starting at 1v. This should be fun...my thinking is that this board has more than one issue. I can definitely tell it has been messed with before. The hold down tab on the keyboard connector is gone & the battery connector is a little melted. Like someone baked the board. This came out of a MBA that someone gave to me as they bought a new machine so if I mess up I am not out any money but if I manage to get somewhere I got priceless knowledge!
